question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned the importance of maintaining lifelong fitness, with walking as an effective cardiovascular exercise. The course emphasized nutrition, strength, flexibility, and recovery, showing how these elements contribute to a healthy lifestyle and can be easily integrated into daily routines.
I mastered proper walking techniques, including posture and gait, which improved my walking efficiency and helped prevent injuries. The course also taught warm-up and cool-down exercises, crucial for preparing the body for exercise and aiding recovery.
The course encouraged walking through various beautiful campus locations, such as Sarah P. Duke Gardens and Duke Pond. These walks not only provided exercise but also improved mental wellness by reducing stress and enhancing mood.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
My perspective and approach to working out dramatically changed as a result of this course and Maria’s motivation. 
I learned
1) how to correlate exercise with wellness and not metrics alone

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed so many skills and insights. Taking from what one girl said in the last day of class “self-care is an upward spiral” and I very much so agree with that. I learned that setting aside time to workout and take care of myself isn’t selfish or slacking off, its necessary and good. I learned that in a male dominated space, safety and comfort is found in numbers so grabbing some of my girl friends and going to the gym is the best way for all of us to get in the gym and actually get to work on our goals rather than simply stating them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to create my own workouts - I always did sports and sports specific workouts, but those were created for me by coaches and PTs, so I had no idea how to do it myself
2. How to be more comfortable in the gym - the gym always scared me, especially since everyone always seemed so confident and strong and I was afraid they’d all know I had no idea what I was doing, but now I’m so much more confident in showing up and working out:) 
3. How to use TRXs!! They’re so useful but I only ever knew how to do one or two basic exercises with them, so it’s super cool that I know all these new exercises now

response_text: Coach Cole is an amazing basketball coach, and you can tell he genuinely cares about each and every one of his students. He treats every class as an opportunity to help some of us young folk develop skills that we can take into the real world, even outside of basketball. Every tuesday (or thursday, I can't remember lol) he does this thing he calls "Two Cents Tuesday" where he offers a life lesson that can be used in basketball, but that can also be used in the real world. Each week he comes up with something different, and each one is genuinely impactful. You can tell he really takes his job seriously, and cares about the kids in his class. He wants them to succeed, and will do everything he can to make sure that happens.

response_text: Coach Cole is not only my favorite teacher I've had a Duke, he is probably my favorite person I've met at Duke. I say this in the most sincere way possible. I've taken this course 3 times now, (hopefully going to take it once more for my final semester, fingers crossed), and not only can I say that I have significantly improved my basketball skills, I can also say that this class has helped me grow as a person. The course itself is surprisingly very balanced, (I would have thought that mostly insane basketball players would show up), yet the class is a mix of new players and experienced players alike. Nobody is unbeatable, and Coach makes the teams in such a way that you find yourself feeling like you can make a difference in the game, even if you aren't the strongest player. So to any prospective student that is thinking about this class, I would say that you will improve your game a ton, but also learn some valuable life lessons, and gain a valuable mentor for the future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Jannis is an incredibly kind and skilled tennis teacher. Definitely recommend taking a class with her if you're considering taking a PE class at Duke. However, I enrolled in tennis 1 with some prior tennis experience and found the pace of the course to be quite slow. If you are torn between tennis 1 and 2, consider tennis 1 a class for someone who has never played tennis before. It starts with the very basics of tennis and you aren't able to rally/play games until a couple weeks into the semester. If you'd consider yourself and athlete or someone who's able to pick up sports quickly, take tennis 2.

Understanding Rules and Scoring — I gained a comprehensive understanding of the rules, terminology, and scoring system of pickleball, which was essential for effective gameplay.
Developing Core Skills — I learned and practiced fundamental skills, including dinks, serves, volleys, and overhead shots, which significantly improved my control and technique on the court.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Steven Kaufman was incredible. He led individual exercises to help with chi, such as push hands, cloud hands, or silk reeling, as well as group instruction on the form, where we learned movement combinations that define the Chen short form of Tai Chi. He took time for questions and individual instruction. The flexibility between these 3 methods made for the perfect combination in my opinion- there was time dedicated to the key skills and bodily prerequisites that enable a good practice of Tai Chi, the written form to test and exercise those skills, and individualized coaching and expertise to refine that practice. I’d keep it all.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My main takeaway from this course was how the practice of yoga came about, its purpose, and how I can implement its lessons and effects into my daily life. Things like breathing techniques (particularly box breath) were things that I learned in this course and through the encouragement of Coach Maria, I felt really empowered to implement these techniques throughout the day, beyond the mat. My favorite thing I learned was sun salutations because I feel like it was the most accessible way to bring yoga practice into my daily routine and we practiced it so much, that it felt like muscle memory and I eventually felt confident enough in the movements to be able to tune in to the mindfulness aspect of yoga.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I didn't love yoga bingo but think I was also in a bad mood that day. The class create-a-flow was a cool experiment and one I hope was empowering for the class!I'm not sure if it was the personalities in the class or the class' structure but I think we could do more to create community within the class. In most yoga classes you have varying schedules, drop-ins, and other things that cause the people in your class to change very frequently. Having a semester-long yoga class provides a unique opportunity to practice alongside the same people for three months! While you can't necessarily do some of the things you do around public yoga classes to build community (grab a post-session beer or do a pre-session run/workout), I'm sure there are more collaborative exercises we could do at the beginning of class (like when we introduced our classmate next to us).

response_text: Everything was fantastic. I love that we learned a little about the yoga teachings in the beginning of each class. Maria is a fantastic teacher. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Maria is fantastic. She is such a supportive yoga teacher and she is always mindful of our limits. She really teaches us to become aware of our limits and never try to push ourselves beyond them. What I thought was most remarkable is how maybe in our 1st or 2nd class, she said I will never touch you or physically guide you during our sessions, unless you ask for it or I have your full consent. Having practiced yoga outside of Duke, I feel most teachers are not aware of this boundary people may have. She really created an entirely safe space throughout our semester together.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed how each class worked up to a “super adventure” pose that allowed us to push ourselves as far as we desired. Later on in the semester, as those poses got harder, Maria gave us time at the end of class to play with the super adventure poses and try them as many times as we liked with her 1:1 advice if so requested. This allows students of different skill levels to learn the poses to an extent that made sense for them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me so much! I learned about different exercise training programs to align with exercise goals, like increasing max strength, power, and hypertrophy. I learned how metabolism fuels the body through ATP production, and learned about the ATP-PC system and how important it is for max effort exercise. Lastly, I learned how the cardiovascular and respiratory systems work hand in hand to deliver oxygenated blood to our bodies at rest and during exercise.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned more about why what I eat makes me feel as it does, especially when working out, and how I can maximize my benefits for desired outcomes in the gym and overall.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how different physiological processes unfold within our bodies during exercise. This included information on the nervous, muscular, cardiovascular, and respiratory systems, nutrition, metabolism, and the various adaptations that occur within our bodies in response to exercise. I learned about different training and lifestyle approaches that athletes can (and oftentimes should) take so as to maximize their performance and the physiological explanations behind why these approaches are effective.

response_text: The course was a once a week class which I personally loved. The structure with the muscle cell information first and the metabolism/pulmonary system in the second half worked very well. The instructor has certainly thought out the course structure with the idea of maximizing learning for the students. The chapter quizzes keep everyone accountable but are also not too difficult and allow for makeups. The exams were fair and the information that we needed to understand for them was quite clear from the powerpoints. There were also many interactive elements, like the presentations, which really allowed you to focus on something you were personally interested at greater depth. I wish they were more spread out or that you only had two presentations.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is relatively laid back with only meeting once a week, but don't let that tempt you to slack on your work. Staying on top of assignments and doing the readings will really help you excel in this course, and be sure to participate in class as much as you can to get practice with the course content. This class is really interesting and puts a fun perspective on physiology than a basic anatomy course. You get to see real world implications of everything you learn, which is a huge plus if you benefit from seeing where your course content shows up in real life. Highly recommend taking this course with Kim because she's the best and really cares about her students and their performance in class!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the most impactful lessons was the emphasis on modeling the behavior and attitude you want to see in others. As we discussed in class, great leaders in sports earn respect by demonstrating commitment, discipline, and resilience on and off the field. For example, I learned how small actions, like showing up early to practice or maintaining a positive attitude during tough moments, can set the tone for the entire team. This concept has inspired me to focus on being consistent and accountable in my own leadership. Another key takeaway was the concept of situational leadership. The course taught me that there’s no one-size-fits-all approach to leading a team. Depending on the group’s needs whether it’s motivating after a loss or strategizing for a game leaders must adapt their style. I practiced this skill through group activities, where I experimented with being more directive in some cases and collaborative in others. This flexibility has made me more effective in supporting teammates and achieving shared goals.

I would suggest retaining these assignments in future courses, as they encourage introspection and the practical application of course content.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific skills/pieces of knowledge I developed in this course were reading comprehension skills, public speaking/presentation abilities, and an overall deeper understanding of how to think critically about my own nutritional/health choices. First, through the readings, analysis of articles, current event assignment, and midterm, I continued to develop the skill of reading comprehension and thoroughly reading an article. Next, through the final project, small in-class group presentations, and book talk, I was able to grow in my public speaking and presentation skills. And finally, through the different speakers and in-class lectures, I was given the space to think critically about my own nutritional/health choices.
